Welcome to /k/, 4chan's weapons board. Our board centers around weapons, armor, and other myriad military technology. While guns are the primary topic, threads involving any other sort of weapons, from swords and knives to tanks and jet fighters, come up frequently as well. If you're new, we suggest reading the sticky at http://amagicalplace.wikia.com/wiki/Sticky to get acquainted with the board's subject matter.

Before posting a thread, please check our catalog to ensure that a thread about the same topic does not already exist.

last_replies.com:
>>56327762
>Casting.
You can cast most metals anon, including steel. It doesn't have to be bronze. Bronze is not unique in its ability to be cast. It's just relatively easy compared to many other metals because of its fairly low melting point. That was relevant historically but it doesn't matter today.

>Same would be true of use as a slide. Incredibly easy to make.
Casting alone isn't close to precise enough to make a functional slide. You'd have to cast it roughly to shape, then finish machine it. And the finish machining is the big complex step. It would cost more for you to ship your slide back to the manufacturer for recasting than it would for them to just buy a piece of steel. Nevermind the fact that slides very rarely wear out. This is a bad solution to a non-extant problem.

Even if he's way off and it's 20 tpi that's still far to fine for a standard thread of that diameter. It's also an oddball diameter. It's too large for M22 and too small for M24, the next size up. Likewise it's too small for 7/8 inch and too small for 1 inch.

com:

Slow general edition

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

com: Why haven't the Soviets ever considered developing the An-225 into a Strategic Bomber? Just imagine a bomber that can carry 250 tonnes worth of bombs?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56344516
Networked battlefields aren't a guarantee. That's actually why I picked maritime patrol as an example. In contested waters, you'll have planes over those waters, it also being contested airspace. Losing a few planes creates significant gaps in coverage, and will happen. If you lose the drone that was shadowing ships, the C-130 has zero ability to attack those ships now. It's much easier and cheaper to saturate a land based theatre with sensors.

Okay I thought of another way to explain this. Most targets that Rapid Dragon is good against are in situations where almost any plane can launch some kind of missile at a target. Other planes have so much better capability without endangering critical logistical capability. The C-130 is too vulnerable and important to commit to combat.

Okay, let's imagine a scenario. It's going to be a situation where the enemy is temporarily vulnerable, play along. Some primary and secondary objectives are potential targets in an area defended by SAMs. You send F-35s in first for SEAD, assuming you have good intel on all SAM sites. The enemy will either lose their SAMs and/or they'll quickly pack them up and move them in reaction, meaning you've cleared time for a bombing run. You'd much rather have B-2s than C-130s, even if they're both carrying the same number of missiles. The C-130 can only blow its load at once, attacking all targets, primary and secondary, at once. The B-2 can target the primary targets, expend a few missiles, wait for confirmation, and if your missiles got surprise intercepted then it's still possible to try again. The F-35s can take care of the surprise missile defense system, and the B-2 tries again. You can't do that with the C-130.

Can anyone think of a mission where you'd want to risk a C-130 in combat?

>Can the based Chinks engineer a good rifle or LAT weaponry?
They absolutely can, type 56s are regularly held up as the best AKs around, but they often wont it often comes down to which factory. Polytech AKs were great, Mak90s (norinco) had issues, export type 56s (factory no.66) were considered better than the soviet AKs by communist satellites.
>Is QBZ-95 with its 5.8×42mm ammunition a competitive rifle?
The QBZ is basically an AK receiver with an SKS piston and non-free floated barrel (even after updating it); so you can expect similar performance to an AK in terms of accuracy. The wildcard is the ammo, the chinks say its better than 5.56 but you cant trust them. On paper is functionally the same as 5.56 in terms of velocity and muzzle energy, but about 20% heavier and with a steel core. If true, that would put it incrementally ahead of western steel core (M855/M855A1), but not to the extent that it would matter in any practical capacity. Another aspect is optics, the chinks certainly do mass issue dovetail optics but not to everybody. It cant be downplayed what a boon optics are for situational awareness, IFF and being able to hit targets even with an inaccurate gun, so PLA units who are unfortunate enough to not be issued optics are at a massive disadvantage to their American peers.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56340367
Both M855 and M855A1 will fragment to similar degrees so the average wound is not necessarily noticeably different in severity. The draw of M855A1 ballistically is supposed to be that it does so much more consistently. M855 stops fragging below ~2500 FPS whereas M855A1 appears to do so down to at least 1700 FPS, and normal M855 occasionally fails even above 2500 FPS at more or less random because yaw dependent lawl.

>>56343372
There are a couple different candidates based on application.
Black Hills 77 gr TMK for damage on unprotected targets, wind resistance, and expansion range.
62 gr Gold Dot for a good combination of flesh performance, range, and barrier blindness.
M855A1 seems to trade some behind-barrier terminal performance for better barrier penetration.
FBIT3 and RA556B if you’re super autistic about post-barrier performance at the cost of, well, basically everything else.

As a Vietnam veteran, I have struggled with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) for many years. The constant flashbacks, anxiety, and insomnia can make daily life feel unbearable at times. But recently, I discovered a new hobby that has helped me cope with my PTSD: using a varmint rifle.

Varmint hunting allows me to focus on a specific task, and the act of aiming and shooting the rifle provides a sense of control and accomplishment. The peacefulness of the outdoors and the satisfaction of hitting my target has been incredibly therapeutic for me.

Not only has varmint hunting helped me manage my symptoms of PTSD, but it has also provided me with a sense of camaraderie and community. I have met other veterans who share my passion for hunting, and spending time with them has been a valuable source of support and friendship.

Overall, using a varmint rifle has been a lifesaver for me and has greatly improved my quality of life. If you are a veteran struggling with PTSD, I highly recommend giving varmint hunting a try.

Total Ceran XS 80. fully synthetic calcium sulfonate grease. smooth, no tack. has the consistency of warm butter.

>>56341664
Finally, if you think hiding in a mineshaft or bunker will save you in a conventional war, thermobaric weapons operate by causing the immediate atmosphere for 100's of ft around the thermobaric explosion to experience a double digit change in psi, if you put one at the mouth of the mineshaft it'll suck all the air out and kill you all the same and it's likely to fuck up your oxygen exchange equipment. Soldiers on both sides are also looking for safe places to hide equipment caches and are also looking for supplies, and unlike average civillians, they have the expertise and tools to get into those bunkers you see being built on YT. IMO, if you're in a warzone and cannot get out for years on end, best thing to do is find a inactive mineshaft or quarry, prep yourself to move farther into the mineshaft as needed e.g. quick erecting barriers and quickly constructed traps in reinforced positions further into the mine, and set yourself up to live deep underground in the mine for a long-ass while. YT has tons of videos on mines and mineshaft exploration. It's a project but if you can pull it off and manage to even have an underground aquafer access, it's the best way to go, especially if you have masonry and carpentry skills.

If you want to see how it's done correctly, look at how the Finnish and Swedish build their bunkers. They have DUMBs for most of their citizenry to retreat to in case of a war and the engineering on some of the larger military bunkers is phuenominal.

last_replies.com:
>>56340463
>Reloading is a big learning curve
Not really. If you're fucking around outside of published recipes or doing something otherwise weird and out of the way like .43 Egyptian then you absolutely need to have a good grounding but the kind of reloading that ninety nine people out of a hundred exclusively do requires little more than attention to detail (especially with modern data and in a modern rifle) and a respect for the fact that if you fuck up you could lose a gun and/or your eye.

>>56340496
>realistically, is it even possible to download .223 to the power of a .22lr?
Depends on the .22 in question. Something like a CCI stinger, sure. Something like subsonic match ammo, probably not. Bullet selection for terminal effect also can be a bit tricky if you want your bullet to do anything besides just pencil.

>won't it be difficult for the primer to set off the round with so much air in the powder space?
With most powders, yes. With Trail Boss, no. More importantly, using that little of a standard powder without some sort of packing is quite dangerous because dude pressure spikes lmao.

>and will it even push the bullet out of a 20" barrel?
Sure, no problem.

>>56340730
Trail Boss is fucking rad. I used it to work up some reduced loads when I was first getting used to my new rifle and it helped my marksmanship a lot.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

If bringing your .223 down to <1500 FPS with Trail Boss isn't enough for you then I would say just bite the bullet and get either a .22 or a .22 mag. Or if you have a grand burning a hole in your pocket and don't mind paying $2/rd. then you could go for a rifle in .22 Hornet, which straddles the line between .22 mag and something like .223.

com:
I don't really understand why the Excalibur is useful. It costs around the same as a GMLRS missile.
Why not just use gun artillery for what it is meant for and use a missile for what it is best at precision strikes?

It seems like they are just reinventing the wheel here for no good reason.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Excalibur consumes less space. But by the same token, going to precision frees up more logistics volume (about 20x) than rockets consume (they're 4-5x the space of artillery).
So there's really not that much gained by staying with 155s because why use a smaller warhead if you don't need to? There is such a thing as too small. A 155 is ok, and a 2000lb bomb is usually too much, but if it all costs the same why not use a 50lb to 200lb warhead, which is a size which provides the max reliability of kill without going into the collateral-damage issue scale.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Well for tube artillery you can bring a large amount of cheap normal shells and a smaller amount of precision shells, while for missile launchers dumb rockets are fucking useless.

So you can get a few heavy duty long range missile launching platforms with precision munitions(meaning high effect on target and long range), or you can distribute your precision munitions among your pre-existing tube artillery(meaning higher tactical availability and dispersion) or better yet, do both. A smaller amount of missile systems for strategic priority targets, and a smaller amount of distributed smart artillery shells for targets of opportunity.
